citations.narrative:
Several enclosures housing approximately 6 adult dogs contain excessive chew damage. The chew damage is located on
the frame around the door between the indoor and outdoor sections of each enclosure. Damaged surfaces cannot be
properly sanitized and can create sharp points that can cause injury to the animals. All surfaces must be maintained on a
regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities—including houses, dens, and other furniture-type fixtures and objects within
the facility—that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled. Correct by ensuring that
all surfaces are maintained or replaced when worn or soiled.

An enclosure housing two wolf hybrids has wood fence posts that are not impervious to moisture. Additionally, a shelter
provided for three adult dogs in an enclosure contains exposed pallets that are not impervious to moisture. Surfaces in
contact with the animals that are not impervious to moisture can absorb moisture and harbor bacteria while being unable
to be properly cleaned and sanitized exposing the dogs to unnecessary disease hazards. Correct by ensuring that all
enclosures, den boxes and furniture type fixtures are designed and constructed of materials that are impervious to
moisture and able to be properly cleaned and sanitized or removed/replaced once they become worn or soiled.

The facility is not protecting animals from injury:
-An outdoor primary enclosure housing three adult dogs contains an approximately 20-foot section of fence line with a
significant tilt of about 45 degrees. A fence with a significant tilt could potentially collapse onto the animals causing injury
and distress.
-An enclosure housing an adult Siberian Husky has exposed sharp points. The metal fencing is broken on both sides of
the outside run creating sharp points that are accessible to the animal. Sharp points can cause injury to the animals.
Correct by ensuring that primary enclosures are constructed and maintained so that they protect the dogs from injury.

The facility is in need of housekeeping. In the area directly adjacent to the enclosures housing ten adult raccoons, there
was a large accumulation of debris including pallets, plastic siding, and rolls of metal fencing. Accumulations of debris can
provide areas which can harbor disease-transmitting pests and could increase health risks to the animals. Correct by
ensuring that premises (buildings and grounds) are kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from
injury and to facilitate prescribed husbandry practices. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated areas and
cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 19-May-2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
Jonathan Tomkovitch, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.1(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Several enclosures housing approximately 6 adult dogs contain excessive chew damage. The chew damage is located on 
the frame around the door between the indoor and outdoor sections of each enclosure. Damaged surfaces cannot be 
properly sanitized and can create sharp points that can cause injury to the animals. All surfaces must be maintained on a 
regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities—including houses, dens, and other furniture-type fixtures and objects within 
the facility—that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled. Correct by ensuring that 
all surfaces are maintained or replaced when worn or soiled. 
3.4(c) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
An enclosure housing two wolf hybrids has wood fence posts that are not impervious to moisture. Additionally, a shelter 
provided for three adult dogs in an enclosure contains exposed pallets that are not impervious to moisture. Surfaces in 
contact with the animals that are not impervious to moisture can absorb moisture and harbor bacteria while being unable 
to be properly cleaned and sanitized exposing the dogs to unnecessary disease hazards. Correct by ensuring that all 
enclosures, den boxes and furniture type fixtures are designed and constructed of materials that are impervious to 
moisture and able to be properly cleaned and sanitized or removed/replaced once they become worn or soiled. 
3.6(a)(2)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The facility is not protecting animals from injury: 
-An outdoor primary enclosure housing three adult dogs contains an approximately 20-foot section of fence line with a 
significant tilt of about 45 degrees. A fence with a significant tilt could potentially collapse onto the animals causing injury 
and distress. 
-An enclosure housing an adult Siberian Husky has exposed sharp points. The metal fencing is broken on both sides of 
the outside run creating sharp points that are accessible to the animal. Sharp points can cause injury to the animals. 
Correct by ensuring that primary enclosures are constructed and maintained so that they protect the dogs from injury. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation.

The facility is in need of housekeeping. In the area directly adjacent to the enclosures housing ten adult raccoons, there 
was a large accumulation of debris including pallets, plastic siding, and rolls of metal fencing. Accumulations of debris can 
provide areas which can harbor disease-transmitting pests and could increase health risks to the animals. Correct by 
ensuring that premises (buildings and grounds) are kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from 
injury and to facilitate prescribed husbandry practices. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated areas and 
cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 19-May-2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Jonathan Tomkovitch, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
